												This game is like eating three pints of ice cream while watching your favorite movie. You have this sinking feeling that something or someone may judge you, but you know what? It tastes good and it just FEELS SO RIGHT.This is a very well thought out dating sim game and I'm happy to still be waist deep within it. Your task is to help your boss, Kitty Powers, make perfect matches. Send your clients off on their dream dates and make sure they don't blow it.Simple enough, right? Not quite. There are types of people to mix and match together while hoping that date goes perfectly. Will it take one perfect date or do you want to steam it out with three dates? Guide your clients by playing mini games to make sure they succeed in winning the affections of their date.If you succeed, you get promotions and you get paid. Getting paid means better restaurants to take dates to, better ways to fancy up your clients (because they REALLY need your help), and other little perks like kicking out the more troublesome clients.The tutorial makes things look incredibly easy, but once that's done, you are almost completely on your own and left figuring out things for yourself. You'll have to understand clients interests and how your little black book works. You'll either figure this out through dumb luck or failing. Either way, there's no harm in making a few mistakes at first. No one's perfect starting out. Even I have a completely ruined relationship from a client that I thought were totally into each other. Oh well, win some and lose some.I love that you get updates from satisfied customers and you get perks from their continuing relationships. I thought that this was a great touch and another incentive to get things right the first time. Another thing that I loved? Making my own profile to send out myself to be a "mystery shopper" for my own dating life. Can't wait to see the results to have a good laugh over that.The graphics are bright and inviting, reminding me of traditional time management games. And those games? Those games remind me of addiction. They remind me of "just one more level". That's what I noticed immediately. I wanted one more date conquered just because I needed the ego boost. Just to say I was Kitty's best employee (I have no friends playing this so this is my wild imagination), I needed to do more work for more upgrades. Just ONE MORE client! It's very friendly and I'm almost happy that Kitty isn't cartoony because that would take away from the humor that is our wonderful and loving boss. She is quite sassy and pixels just wouldn't suit her, after all.I especially appreciated that there was a bit more inclusion in this game. It's not just limited to man-seeking-woman or woman-seeking-man, the devs did realize there's more than man and woman relationships so I must say I appreciated that option. Thank you. It means a lot that you did that.There is a bit of stereotyping...but more so on the personality types of "sporty", "nerds", "hippies", etc. If that offends you then I have no idea what to say. If you have trouble with characters who are supposed to be "punk alternative" speaking with what seems like (forgive if I read it in the wrong accent!) a Cockney/London accent then steer clear. Seriously. British Punks from London stereotypes. I can't imagine anyone hating that but hey, they're there amongst a few other cliches. I thought they were all incredibly adorable characters I really, desperately wanted to see happy. They're very "human" with wants and needs and the need to be validated.Even for cartoon people without souls, yes. I'm entirely serious.The more things you buy for your matchmaking business, the harder things get. If you buy better restaurants, you get paid more, but the games get harder and sometimes slightly lewd. Yes there is a game to hold in your fart. The fact I can write a review complimenting a game for recognizing that yes, you have to hold in your gas during a date and it is indeed a game of chance is astounding. I never thought I'd have to compliment a fart mini game.Buy a salon for your business and you can alter your appearance for a better potential mate for your client. Wouldn't that one guy or gal be great IF ONLY your client dyed their hair lilac? Now you can...if you do it quickly. Does that guy/gal prefer a more chic style? Quickly change clothes after you buy an add-on for your salon. They say you shouldn't change for anyone but hey, let's make an exception, right?It's an easily accessible game that truly anyone can play. While I'd keep this for the crowd that can understand dating, I'd honestly say this is really a decent game for anyone to play. It's cute. It's bubbly. You can play against your friends and compare scores. You can even send your friends personas on dates if they're playing. You get bonus points for making matches with real life people and you'll tell who they are by the little globe by their profile as you match them up to people.I can't find a single thing bad about this game, really. It's a little tycoon/sim on dating and it really illustrates the whole luck/chance and repetition that is dating. And I'm not bored! There's always some new curve ball coming at me!Plus Kitty Powers is the best boss I have ever had. If I could just do this in real life with Kitty as my real boss, this would be great.

												I bought this of sheer boredom.And I hate to admit it, but it's actually a lot of fun, challenging, and incredibly addictive, though it's nothing more than a gloryfied memory game.Played 4 hours in my first session, and I'm nowhere near having everything unlocked, and have yet to get my first achievement.Basically, you run a dating service, and your job is to pair up couples successfully, by comparing attractions, interests and personality types.Take them on dates, pay sincere compliments (or lie), and keep dates interesting by selecting different conversation topics. While on dates, you get to play different mini-games (mostly memory oriented, as far as I can tell after playing 4 hours).And occasionally, something incredibly funny happens, and it actually made me LOL af few times.Personalities consist of 5 different traits, each with 2 different mindsets and behaviors connected to them.Combining these with a ton of different interests, jobs, hair styles and colours, clothes style, eye colours and make-up (for women), and facial hair (for men), and different accessories, makes up a dating pool with tremendous variety.And this variety is what makes the game interesting.The really brilliant part of this game is, that you start of by creating your own character, by customizing looks to your own preferences, and answer a series of questions to determine your own personality type.And (if you allow) this character will then become a dating option for other players to pair you up.And the game will then send you notifications on how your 'virtual self' does in the dating world, depending on other players choices and skills to determine your personality type.Your character is given a fake name if allowed in other players games.....just in case you're the kind to worry about such things.And as you successfully pair up couples and earn reputation, you unlock different things to add further variety to the game.Such as extented dating options, different restaurants with different difficulty levels, and pre-dating alteration options that allows you to change clothes or hair styles, colours, make-up, or buy gifts to impress your date.This is a well constructed casual game, well worth the price tag, if you're into games you can pick up and leave at any time.I have no problems recommending this game - much to my own surprise.

That took me quite a long time (and about four approaches), but finally I got to pair-up Kitty, so I consider it some form of ending. I've restarted game few times (as I don't like to pick up where I left after long break), and first few dates are always the most interesting and engaging, but once the initial feeling of uniqueness wears off, the content gets very repetitive. Also, I find pairing up low-star folks more enjoyable - it's much easier and dates go very fast, when compared to three star customers or VIPs. Those are, understandably, more demanding, but not nearly enough rewarding, to make it fun, instead of frustrating.Despite my lack of interest, I still give this game a positive review, as it does many things right - I loved the art style, Kitty is amazing, there are funny moments, good mini-games and great ideas thrown there. I'm waiting for a next game from Magic Notion, hoping that it will turn out to be more engaging, because the potential is definitely there. If you like dating games, I recommend to pick this one out during sale and see if it's something you enjoy.

Serious review (Humorous, non serious review below): This game is... interesting. You create a character, that is supposed to be "You". You choose your looks, your personality traits, your birthday which is also your star sign (Gemini, Aquarius, etc.) Your first date you set up you cannot mess up, as it's the tutorial that's running you through how to play. You choose your venue that you want to act as a matchmaker for. Each venue has different people's personalities. You do kinda feel like a third wheel on the dates, since you're just silently watching them. The goal is to pick up on verbal cues by the dates and give them the best experience. Make the right comments, order the right food based on the hints they give, etc. You can date other peoples character profiles as well. You get coins that are used as a currency to buy upgrades and other things to help you. The better you do, the more coins you are tipped at the end, the higher your reputation goes up, and the more you matchmaking you can do. All in all, it's a pretty interesting game and if you like the idea of setting people up on the perfect date, then it's worth a try.Humorous, non serious review:I am Lord Tippington, a balding, introverted, antisocial, nerd. 												There are lots of dating simulators out there, but none of the (admittedly few) I've tried has drawn me in like Kitty Powers' Matchmaker. The gameplay is casual gaming at its best, with a bunch of minigames, some simple, others a bit more complicated but all of them fun (except for one, the pachinko game, which is basically a lottery). Playing a date or two is a good filler between longer games, but it's also fun to sink a whole evening into the virtual dating agency.It's a very charming game, fronted by the lovely Kitty Powers herself and full of nice jokes that are so bad that they flip over and become good.What I like the most, though, and what sets it apart from other dating sims I've played, is the way the developers seem to have thought about what dating is and what makes for a good relationship. The dates are all about paying attention to the prospective partner and trying to find common ground. Not only do you get points for pairing off your customers, but you will also get letters with updates on how the relationship worked out in the long run. This means that even though you can speed through a date, hide your weaknesses and pull a few "white lies", you will need to be honest and find really good matches to get those A+ results (necessary for getting the baby achievement). All this adds up to a fun, charming and well-designed game which I recommend with all of my heart!

												While this obviously lends itself to easily written silly games, this is one probably the most fun - if dopey - casual/tycoon game I've ever played. I honestly don't even know how to describe what I like about it. It's just plain fun. Instead, here is the small list of things I don't like about it, compiled over my admittedly meager 1.5 hours played (in my defense, I bought this at 1 AM on a Monday morning).-Loading seems to happen all the time. If there's a different 2D background for the 2D characters, there will be a load screen, and they're often relatively long. I can usually load a new area in heavily modded Skyrim at least as quickly as KPM can load the lewdly named American restaurant. I feel like load screens and load times both should be pretty minimal for something like this, but I'm no expert, and it's not horrid. Just annoying.-It can get a little samey, and it's probably not something most people want to sit down and play for more than a couple hours because of that. The dialog is modular (i.e. there are probably 5-10 different ways of saying "I like your hair" and any other conceivable saying), but you see them a lot. After 30-45 minutes of playing, I stopped reading the unimportant dialog because it wasn't funny or interesting after seeing it a few times in that time. It was still fun, just a little less immersive, especially because it felt like the same people talking. Also, unless things change further in, the dates are all just dinner at a restaurant that consist of a few random minigames from a small pool. While they do vary from each other a little and it's a good formula, it does get old.-A lot of the difficulty of the game seems to stem from its randomness. Randomness is kind of a necessity in a game like this, but I think it has a little too much influence. It's very hard to predict how your client's date is going to react to what you say or the decisions you make, and I think there should be more reliable guesswork, if that makes sense. But maybe I just need to play more to understand. I do like that failing a client too much makes them leave and hurt your rep a lot - I almost got to a third strike with one client and I had to do everything I could to make their last date work out.-I'm not sure if I'd pay the full $10 for this game, just because it remains to be seen to me how much the gameplay fleshes out, but I got it on GMG for $6 and that was definitely worth it. At time of posting, it was $7.49 on Steam, which I would have paid if not for the GMG deal.All that said is just overanalysis of things that weren't big deals. The art is fitting, the voice work and images for the one persistent character is hilarious and well done, and the gameplay is enjoyable and error-free. If you're looking to play a game all day, this probably isn't it, but it's definitely something you can keep on hand and get a few hours of fun out of. It also throws your friends' characters in the game as potential clients/dates, so you can have some fun with that if you can convince someone else to play it. I also plan to break it out at LAN parties so my friend Brian can laugh at me and call me rude names.

I'm Hobbes Bauer, and this is the longest day of my life...Some days you get a review, and you know it's fate. Where the game picks you, as much as you pick the game. Kitty Powers is one such game. It's a strange beast, being made up of one part casual coating, one part extremely devious memory games and puzzle minigame, and one part hideous pink topping. Had this been the same mechanics in any other presentation (say, a popcap game), this game would be literally flying off of digital shelves all over the place. The problem stems from well, the insane use of pink, but more of that shortly. Let's get into what the game is about.A dating simulator that's actually mechanically interesting? Say it ain't so!You are a fresh hire in the ever expanding world of the Kitty Powers Matchmaking empire. You have been given a franchise branch in a city, and it's your job to service the city by matching people up and sending them off to find love and happiness (or at least make you enough money to keep you in profit). To this end Kitty Powers furnishes you with two hundred "Kitty Coins", a Kitty Powers office which would make Kerry Katona weep tears of joy, and introduces you with a step by step tutorial that teaches you the ins and outs of the basics of the game, as well as introducing you to some of the most basic of the minigames you'll encounter.Once you've completed your first tutorial date, the training wheels come off, and you can use your Kitty coins to purchase anything that's within your level. As you successfully complete dates and match couples, you'll gain reputation and experience, this unlocks more things to spend your coins on, and as it turns out, there's a lot to buy. There's a big selection of restaurants to pick up, there's a wide bevy of make-up customisation to groom your dates before the night out, as well as additional pages in Kitty's book for room for more dates to give you extra leeway in selecting possible date options. In short, this game has depth, which is surprising, it will take you time, quite a bit of it, if you want to see everything.Each restaurant comes with its' own unique events, along with a generic pool that means each restaurant encounter will be different, along with the conversation system (where you "pull the love handle", deities help me, that's a thing now) which not only requires you to remember the personality types of each date, but enforces harsh penalties if you repeat topics, not just on the same date, but on previous dates as well. For a supposedly casual game, this one doesn't pull its' punches when it comes to the memory mini-games and layering on the difficulty over multiple dates. You get reminders about topics covered and restaurants visited with a given couple, but the game will make damn sure that you're kept on your toes. It might -look- casual, but under that cute exterior, this game has a rather steely spine.Mechanically excellent, graphically chintzy...It's all presented in this smooth, glossy casual style that immediately evokes memories of Popcap games, and has that easy, big button approach that makes it very straightforward, and friendly to those even with poor fine motor skills (even if the humour sails terribly close to the wind on many an occasion). The art style is very, very consistent, albeit in many cases you're going to wish that the designers had a volume dial and they used it to tone the damn thing down, the game uses neon pink liberally. Great for calibrating your monitor, not great for your eyes, have ice buckets on standby if you intend to play more than half an hour at a time.Herein lies the great contradiction at the heart of the game, the mechanics are good, and in any other game there's the foundation and the scaffolds of something really good. This game hasn't got the positive reviews it has just for being he-he-hilarious. It's got them because when you manage to get past the horrific pink, there's a really solid game under the surface. But the visual design is going to deter people, I mean it uses comic sans fer chrissakes. That's not how you win the hearts and minds of some people. But then I have concluded the audience for this game is likely not the traditional audience who plays things like say, Counter Strike or the likes. Still, softening the pink would have helped a lot.Love can be simple, except when it's not...The game does a really good job of translating both the concept of a dating game, something that to now has always been done pretty terribly, and the longer term effects (by sending letters) using good procedural generation techniques. It's managed this by taking itself "not very seriously". This game isn't afraid to poke fun at itself, the loading screens are full of self deprecating humour, the game likes to jibe about various game genres, it asks you to "Pull the love handle" with a straight face, it throws chintz about in the same way Max Payne threw bullets.In turning the whole process of dating, love and romance into this utterly comic and slightly off the wall casual game that's both approachable and yet at the same time potentially really tricky, it strikes a fine balance. As you get into the higher difficulty dates, you'll find the memory games get genuinely hard, like, brain training hard. You'll be asked to remember details that you may not have been paying much attention to ordinarily, you'll be asked to remember and pick out the desert from a list as they roll past, you'll be asked to correctly identify and order food based on vague descriptions. As I said, inside this cute chintzy game, there's a really tough nut in the center.It's just too damned pink.The guilty pleasure of being fabulous...So. Hm. How do I put this. It's good. As much as I grit my teeth and press the button to recommend this, it's actually a good game once you get past the first initial dates and the difficulty ramps up. But you'll need a serious tolerance for the visual design (or a good pair of sunglasses) and probably Clicker Heroes so you can hide what you're doing, lest people stare at your Steam Profile and go "What in the name of gods..."Verdict : Highly Recommended as a guilty pleasure. So do your research first, and/or run Clicker Heroes so people don't start laughing loudly in your chat window.

Play for a few minutes and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the day, or play for a few hours and go on a matchmaking marathon!I find it especially laudable that both Kitty and the developers have stood behind the game and continue to promote it, to encourage videos, and have even made appearances for the game. It pulls you in and has so many things to unlock and discover, there is so much play value to it. At its regular price it's a steal for all it has to offer, but at a sale price, I have to say you should get it immediately.Great game, great fun, and far more entertaining than plenty of the games I've played with a higher profile. 												Kitty Powers' Matchmaker is fun and addicting!  This game is completely unique to anything I've ever played before, and it combines so many elements!  Let's start with clientele!  First you choose a location (disco, gym, comic book store, ect.) for Kitty to set up fliers to attract customers.  The locations you pick determine the type of clients that arrive; for example, choosing the comic book store will bring in the "Geeky" types.  Each client is different, varying in looks, personality, and interests.  Because of the uniqueness of each character, it can be hard finding the right match for your client, but that's what makes it so much fun!  Will your client swing a home-run of strike out on their date(s)?  The actual dates are the most intricate part of the entire game.   Literally everything has a part in determining the success of the date, from choosing a restaurant to holding in your farts!  There are fun mini-games to be played that vary with each establishment you go to.  Leveling up unlocks new restaurants for clients to visit and different features in the salon to beautify your client before the big date!  There is quite a lot of memorization involved in the game, so it can get tough once you reach the higher scoring dates, but I don't believe it distracts from the overall entertainment of the game.  My favorite thing about the game is the mailbox feature.  After successfully setting up your client with a hot date, you will receive mail from he or she updating you on how things are progressing in their new relationship.  Sometimes things go sour and the couple breaks up, but sometimes they'll end up with children and even name one of the babies after you!  It all comes down to how well you do when playing matchmaker.

												This isn't the usual tycoon or even the usual dating sim. This is Kitty Powers's Matchmaking and believe me, it's harder than you think.The one thing that it has in common with other dating/matchmaking games is the ... well, dating and matchmaking. But how you go about it and that fact that you will have all possible couple combinations (which is amazlingly refreshing for once) is different ... and can be quite difficult. There is some guess work and some unexplained features that can make this a little more difficult - for example who is what 'type'. No, not sexuality wise but life style wise. How do you best figure that out. Then you start having to guess some more and make conclusions until you finally realize that someone who loves Halloween might just like someone who enjoys costume parties. It's not black and white - it is not match the same with the same but it is a but find the middle ground. The rest of the set up dates are won or lost with a serious of mini-games and a good memory or the ability to right things down fast. Some are a lot of fun, some not so much  - and some are simply depending on luck.  Depending on your matchmaking skills, memory and luck, the couple will hit it off or not. Coins, XP and reputation are awareded. XP unlocks additional features via level - Coins are required to buy the features, cheat or get hints - and Reputation ... well I only know that the tip you receive for a sucessful case increases with reputation ... but that's all I know. For now, the game does get slightly repetitive but I am hoping to unlock some additional features to spice things up with time. Kitty Power's comments, the ... unusual ways of talking, crazy hobbies and the likes are currently still making up for it. One thing that I am really missing is the means to reset the account. I have the feeling I invested some money in the wrong things at the beginning and would have loved to start over.All in all - it's addictive and challenging and I am bent to crack a good bunch of the achievements.So yes, for the price, I would recommend the game.

												Sooo.. I saw a Let's Play of this game and decided I needed it in my life. The Kitty Powers character - while I don't personally like her - is very reminiscent of the Lily Savage style character, a fun but fabulous drag queen who rocks it. The gameplay itself has you setting up clients with potential dates and trying to make the right matches for them based on personality type and more. It gets pretty nuanced which is pretty cool. But that's not all, you're also a fly on the wall in each date, the client has an earpiece through which you tell them what to say. You have to work out what the date wants to eat from clues like "I want something cold with no meat. And no wheat." You play a slot machine for conversation topics. You'll have to choose whether to lie or tell the truth on some of your answers, whether you think the date will be pleased or not. If you lie, you spin the 'Wheel of Misfortune' to see if you got away with it or not, with the chance of winning bonus coins. The coins you use in the shop to unlock add-ons to the salon where you can do your client up before their date, unlock more pages of potential dates, and unlock more retaurants. Each restaurant unlock adds in a new "thing" in to a date. For example, one restaurant unlock throws in the chance for your client's ex to randomly show up and you have to decide whether to be honest about who it was or lie. The date will either care greatly, or not. If you lie, you get the Wheel of Misfortune and if they don't believe you, as before, it's a strike. You get 3 strikes in a date. If you get 3, they walk out. Oh and if your client gets dumped they get a broken heart. If they are dumped 3 times, they storm out and you lose a bunch of reputation.TL;DR - It's a very pink, camp game with a really fun centre and I'm bloody addicted. But prepare for a British culture slap in the face.. I wouldn't be surprised if they decided to "go for a cheeky Nandos for a bit of bants."

												I have fallen in love and it's all thanks to Kitty Powers!More seriously, this game is incredibly fun and I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a casual game that'll steal hours, and hearts, from them.Story:You're a matchmaker. Make some matches. Try to make REALLY GOOD matches too so that you can make some extra money and make better matches. Gameplay:Simple but effective, each "round" you play is a date for one of your clients. At any date any given "event" might happen, triggering a mini-game; the amount of mini-games it draws from depends on your progression and how many different restaurants you get. The games are fun (if occasionally frustrating!) and don't really get old. Examples: card matching, higher or lower, plinko, spot the difference, etc.It's not surprising to me that this is also a mobile game; however it doesn't necessarily feel like a mobile game ported to the PC, if that makes sense, and I would definitely rather play it on a PC than my phone or a tablet. I do wish there were some integration of the keyboard for mini-games though.Overall my biggest worry about gameplay is always whether or not it detracts from or serves the story. As it's not a story-heavy game, and as the gameplay is quick and casual, I'd say it hits the mark perfectly. Low investment in skill or cognition for an inversely high amount of pleasure.Art and Writing:The art is campy, randomly generated, and absolutely perfect for what the game is. My one complaint here is that ALL of the characters are super thin and cisgender/gender normative? But diversity in appearance, race, and sexuality make for a fun enough romp that I forget that while playing. Kitty Powers herself is absolutely adorable while jumping off the screen, and while I think she's a tongue-in-cheek joke herself (she is a drag queen), the game has so far managed that without dipping into transmisogyny (I'm only level 9 though). The characters are incredibly repetitive, but the combinations of what they say change each time and the new combinations are almost always very funny.Sound and Music:The voice-actor for Kitty Powers is awesome. The character really comes alive even though she completely lacks animation. The rest of the sound? Eh. The music is loud, even when put down all the way to 1 and mostly it just annoys me. That's not terribly surprising, though; I rarely prefer to play games with their music (I like to turn on netflix or similar while playing). Sound effects and character "chatter" (they're not really speaking English) are very nicely done, though.

From the screenshots, one might assume it's another iOS port onto the PC, but this game actually goes way beyond what we've come to expect from iOS games. 												Although I've only played this game for 6 hours, I have to say, this game is one of the better dating simulators (at least from what I know). Instead of going on dates yourself, you guide your clients through their date with the girl/guy you think is right for them. You can also choose which restaurant they go to. The restaurants have 3 levels; easy, medium, and hard. You can also change the way your client looks before your date. If you succeed, they get together. Afterwards, depending on how you acted on the date, they'll break up. They can also get married and have kids if you did well on the date.If you fail (AKA get dumped), you have to try again with another person. If you fail 3 times in a row, they'll leave the agency, and your reputation will drop.Sometimes, you'll get stuck in the middle, and have to go on three dates before you succeed (or fail).
